nodes.bodyText: There is an unexpected space between workflowName and ).
[minor] (p)->p.toString() can be replaced with ProjectIdentifier::toString
Thanks! I will fix them.
Fixed it. Thanks!
What about the case the conflict attempt failed like If failed, xxx?

Do you mean, if the attempt which is kicked by require> failed,  what happen?
In this case the task will fail as usual.
How about moving this block to the above catch (SessionAttemptConflictException ex) { ... } block? Maybe we can remove the Optional?

Of course, we can do.  My intention of this way is that firstly get result of startSession() including exception (especially SessionAttemptConflictException is not error), then the logic goes ahead based on the result.
if we move the logic in catch (SessionAttemptConflictException ex) { ... }, catch {} become large.
In this case it is better to define another method and call it.
What is your thought?

Based on discussion in person, I fixed it.
As result, the code became simple. Thank you for your advice! 🙂
How about moving this line to right after calling callback.startSession()  in the above try { ... } block? Maybe we can remove the Optional?

My intention is same as above. But this code is small.
So I agree with move to try{..}.
Fixed it. Thanks!
I'm wondering if this scope reduction of retry_attempt_name can affect existing workflows...

Yes. There is possibility as discussion in person.
Let me discuss again in a meeting.
Just noticed you've already mentioned it in the document :)
This isn't used?
Ah, correct. Currently not used. Will remove it. Thanks!
When OptionRerunOn.ALL is set, the workflow should be executed regardless it was executed via require operator or not, right? If so, rerunOn == OptionRerunOn.ALL should not depend on requireKicked?
Ah, got it. I had a wrong idea. It's for Check attempt kicker on the diagram.
A space on the left of interval
Thanks! Fixed it.
Spaces on the both sides of + would be better?
Thanks! Fixed it.
Maybe duplicated deep copy?
May be not duplicated, but I should use lastStateParam argument in my understand.
I updated it.
Unnecessary space on the right of digdag retry
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -71,3 +88,8 @@
   ignore_failure: true
   ```
 
+  require> evaluates *ignore_failure* at last of its process. If rerun_on is set and require> run new attempt, the result of new attempt is checked.
+
+## Notes
+- require> has been changed to ignore inherited *retry_attempt_name* parameter. 
+  `digdag retry ` command generates unique retry_attempt_name to run, but it is not passed to require>.

nodes.bodyText: Fixed it. Thanks!
   ```

nodes.bodyText: Just posted a comment https://github.com/treasure-data/digdag/pull/1405/files#r435112975
I fixed it in #1405 and if it become OK, rebase to this PR.
[minor] Space
Fixed it. (Removed the param because of refactoring)
Same as above
Fixed it. (Removed the param because of refactoring)

I'm wondering why this method call always passes ignoreAttemptFailure=true (sorry, a bit too difficult for me 😅.)
Could I ask you the followings?

Add a comment for each case about why target attempt is expected to fail
2. If possible, make this method call pass attemptShouldFail or something deterministic instead of  ignoreAttemptFailure (probably related to https://github.com/treasure-data/digdag/pull/1409/files#r435692688)
After having read all codes in testRerunOnParam() I understand all things. So probably you can ignore the above comment from me.
I will add some additional comments.
Done. Thanks!

Oh, the same check is done above like assertThat(isAttemptSuccess(childStatus), not(previousChildRunFail))?
So we can remove this to make things simpler?
Thanks for your pointing out. I will remove them and argument ignoreAttemptFailure.
Fixed it and refactoring. Thanks for your pointing out.
Is this line needed?
Thanks. I will remove 263 and 264.
Fixed it, thanks.
How about adding a test case of the combination of none and true?
Thanks, I added it. Now all conditions are covered.
How about adding a test case of the combination of all and true?
I added it. Thanks!
Empty line?
